elements.title: Chris Smalls (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Amazon Labor Union founder Chris Smalls (pictured) was one of the leaders in the first successful effort to unionize Amazon warehouse workers in the United States?

elements.title: facial tattoos (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Inuit traditional belief holds that women without facial tattoos would be sent to the land of the crestfallen to spend eternity with smoke coming from their throats and their heads hanging down?

elements.title: Nelson W. Aldrich Jr. (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Nelson W. Aldrich Jr. dedicated his first book to his wife and credited her with having "always propped up my morale", even though they had been separated for seven years?

elements.title: moral equality of combatants (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that moral equality of combatants, regardless of whether they fight for a just cause, is said to be "one of the stickiest problems in the ethics of war"?

elements.title: Earlonne Woods (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Earlonne Woods details the experience of co-hosting the first podcast created entirely while incarcerated in his book, This Is Ear Hustle?

elements.title: Ukrainian Chorus Dumka of New York (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Ukrainian Chorus Dumka of New York, founded in 1949 by immigrants, first toured Ukraine in 1990?

elements.title: WAQX-FM (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that one of the original co-owners of New York state radio station WAQX-FM did much of the construction himself?

elements.title: Roy Flynn (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Yes complained about former manager Roy Flynn getting "Five per Cent for Nothing"—but he said he got nothing?
